Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Connecting Genes to Behaviors in Ostracod Bioluminescent Mating Displays
Award.AbstractNarration:
An unresolved question in biology is how genes contribute to animal behavior. Behaviors are important because they can affect animal survival and reproduction. But with closely related species, similar behaviors can vary. So how can behaviors integral to survival retain their functionality yet also change across species? This project will investigate both the gene-behavior relationship and how it changes using sea fireflies. Many species make glowing displays to attract mates, but these displays differ between species. The gene responsible for making light in these displays, called luciferase, was first described by Dr. Yoshihiro Ohmiya, currently at the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology in Tsukuba, Japan. He and his colleague Dr. Yasuo Mitani will collaborate with the investigator on this project to show how luciferase has changed across sea fireflies. Using techniques developed by Dr. Ohmiya, the investigator will take luciferase from different species and examine how they function to see if any differences can describe changes in their glowing displays.

This project aims to connect genotype to behavioral phenotype using sea fireflies. Sea fireflies create bioluminescent mating displays by secreting globs of mucus where the enzyme luciferase oxidizes the substrate vargulin to produce light. In a single bolus, the amount of light and duration of the biochemical reaction varies between species. The investigator will learn molecular cloning, plasmid construction, and protein expression assays from collaborators who invented these techniques. They will characterize luciferase from a suite of species and test if these enzymes have a differential ability to produce light. These data will be combined with behavioral data to test for a correlation between biochemical function and behavioral display differences between species.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes:

How different genetics lead to differences in behaviors is a grand question in biology. Most genetics are complicated, as are behaviors, and therefore their relationship is difficult to tease apart. Instead, we focus on using well-characterized bioluminescence genes that are important in the mating displays of cypridinid ostracods crustaceans. Males vomit up packets of glowing mucus in different patterns to attract females; with about 100 species (most undescribed to science), each produces a unique Morse-code like display to mate. By characterizing differences in these genes using transgenic yeast, we are attempting to explain how much these differences in genes explain differences in these bioluminescent mating displays between species. During the collaboration in Japan, we discovered that our main approach to answering this question would not work because of biological differences in the genes and the transgenic yeast we wished to use. Future collaboration will use alternative methods to continue the project goals.

 

Intellectual merit:

This system represents a rare opportunity to investigate how strongly differences in genes are for determining differences in behaviors. Currently we have no data because of the setbacks incurred during the project, but goals remain the same as we switch tactics to redress these issues.

 

Broader impacts:

Besides international collaboration, this project also presented the opportunity to advance the system of bioluminescent ostracods. Bioluminescence is widely captivating for people, and thus this system is an easy bridge between real scientific research and natural wonder. During this project, related research was presented at the AIST open house, which was an event open to the public to explore scientific advances.
